bestBHT.bht: An enemy hath done this - the words of a good Husbandman who honors his faithful servants and separates them from the wrong done to his field. The servants, displaying their concern for the true members of the church, want to gather up the weeds so as not to let them harm the wheat. Their zealousness, though, must be examined for any carnal heat mixed in. Distinguishing between false believers and true ones is crucial, as the presence of those who have the form of godliness but lack power calls for careful discernment.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: An enemy hath done this—Kind words these from a good Husbandman, honorably clearing His faithful servants of the wrong done to his field.

Wilt thou then that we go and gather them up?—Compare with this the question of James and John, 'Lord, wilt Thou that we command fire to come down from heaven and consume' those Samaritans? In this kind of zeal there is usually a large mixture of carnal heat.
John Gill: An enemy has done this... meaning, not that the enemy was a man; for he was the devil... but it is an Hebraism; such as in Esther 7:6, 'the man adversary and enemy' is this wicked Haman; and signifies a certain enemy, and one indeed that is an implacable enemy to man.

The servants said unto him, wilt thou then that we go and gather them up? which words express the concern of the ministers of Christ for the true members of the church, comparable to wheat, lest they should receive any damage by the ill examples, and pernicious principles of evil men among them.

They show great regard to the glory of God, and interest of religion, and their readiness to execute any orders Christ should give them; but not willing to proceed of themselves, ask counsel and advice of him.
John Wesley: An enemy hath done this — A plain answer to the great question concerning the origin of evil.
Darnel, in the Church, is properly outside Christians, such as have the form of godliness, without the power.

Open sinners, such as have neither the form nor the power, are not so properly darnel, as thistles and brambles: these ought to be rooted up without delay, and not suffered in the Christian community.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Matthew 13:28, Jesus responds to the observation that there are weeds growing among the wheat by acknowledging that it was an enemy who sowed those weeds. This serves as a reminder that evil exists in the world and that the presence of false believers within the church is not surprising. The response of the servants, who offer to gather up the weeds, shows their concern for the true members of the church, wanting to protect them from the harmful influence of the false believers. However, it also highlights the danger of acting out of zealousness and carnal heat. The presence of weeds in the church, identified as those who have the form of godliness but lack the power, calls for discernment and wisdom in distinguishing between true believers and those who are merely pretenders.

In the face of weeds growing among the wheat, Jesus acknowledges that an enemy has planted them, absolving His faithful servants of any wrongdoing. The servants, expressing concern for the true members of the church, offer to remove the weeds. However, this zeal must be tempered, as it could be driven by carnal heat. The presence of weeds in the church calls for discernment, recognizing those who possess the form of godliness but lack power, while addressing open sinners separately.

An enemy hath done this - the words of a good Husbandman who honors his faithful servants and separates them from the wrong done to his field. The servants, displaying their concern for the true members of the church, want to gather up the weeds so as not to let them harm the wheat. Their zealousness, though, must be examined for any carnal heat mixed in. Distinguishing between false believers and true ones is crucial, as the presence of those who have the form of godliness but lack power calls for careful discernment.

In Matthew 13:28, Jesus acknowledges that an enemy has planted the weeds among the wheat, exonerating His faithful servants from any blame. The servants, expressing concern for the true members of the church, offer to gather up the weeds. However, it is important to be cautious of acting out of zealousness and carnal heat. Recognizing the distinction between false believers, who possess the form of godliness without power, and true believers becomes imperative to maintain a healthy and genuine Christian community.

In the presence of weeds growing alongside the wheat, Jesus acknowledges that it is an enemy who has brought about this situation, clearing His faithful servants of any wrongdoing. The servants, showing their concern for the true members of the church who are like wheat, express their willingness to gather up the weeds. However, it is crucial to approach this task with caution, keeping in mind the potential for misguided zeal and carnal heat. It is essential to distinguish between those who have only the form of godliness without power and those who genuinely embody it.
